Other Information.Test Conditions: 298 K, adsorption time up to 300 min, solution pH=6
Other Information.Additional Info: Adsorption capacity increased by 52.53% and 27.81% compared to MIL-53(Fe) and MIL-53(Al), respectively.

Sieving Mechanism: Size exclusion at sub-nanometer scale, along with hydrogen bonding and coordination effects.

Experimental Validation.Method: Adsorption experiments, FTIR analysis, Langmuir and Freundlich isotherm models, pseudo-second-order kinetic model

Other Information.Additional Info: The material was optimized for synthesis conditions including reaction temperature, ratio of aluminum to iron, and ratio of terephthalic acid to metal ions.

Other Information.Test Conditions: 298 K, adsorption time up to 300 min, solution pH=6
Other Information.Additional Info: Lower adsorption efficiency compared to MIL-53(Fe, Al).

Sieving Mechanism: Size exclusion at sub-nanometer scale, along with hydrogen bonding and coordination effects.

Experimental Validation.Method: Adsorption experiments, Langmuir and Freundlich isotherm models, pseudo-second-order kinetic model

Other Information.Additional Info: Used as a comparison material to evaluate the performance of MIL-53(Fe, Al).

Other Information.Test Conditions: 298 K, adsorption time up to 300 min, solution pH=6
Other Information.Additional Info: Higher adsorption efficiency than MIL-53(Fe) but lower than MIL-53(Fe, Al).

Sieving Mechanism: Size exclusion at sub-nanometer scale, along with hydrogen bonding and coordination effects.

Experimental Validation.Method: Adsorption experiments, Langmuir and Freundlich isotherm models, pseudo-second-order kinetic model

Other Information.Additional Info: Used as a comparison material to evaluate the performance of MIL-53(Fe, Al).
